solution_line_template: She bought {num_shorts} shorts at ${cost_per_short} each so {num_shorts}*{cost_per_short}=${total_cost_shorts}<<{num_shorts}*{cost_per_short}={total_cost_shorts}>>{total_cost_shorts}
She bought {num_shoes} pair of shoes at ${cost_per_shoe} each so {num_shoes}*{cost_per_shoe}=${total_cost_shoes}<<{num_shoes}*{cost_per_shoe}={total_cost_shoes}>>{total_cost_shoes}
The shorts and shoes cost her {total_cost_shorts}+{total_cost_shoes} = ${total_cost_shorts_shoes}<<{total_cost_shorts}+{total_cost_shoes}={total_cost_shorts_shoes}>>{total_cost_shorts_shoes}

We know she spent {total_spent} total and the shorts and shoes cost ${total_cost_shorts_shoes} which left a difference of {total_spent}-{total_cost_shorts_shoes} = ${cost_of_tops}<<{total_spent}-{total_cost_shorts_shoes}={cost_of_tops}>>{cost_of_tops}
She bought {num_tops} tops for a total of ${cost_of_tops} so {cost_of_tops}/{num_tops} = ${cost_per_top}
